messages.subject: Middle timers story
messages.msgSnippet: Well I got busy and forgot to add some sword stories Since I am not an old timer nor new at it I gonna call this middle timers stories. Anyway, in 1990 Bob
messages.messageBody:
Well I got busy and forgot to add some sword stories
Since I am not an old timer nor new at it I gonna call
this "middle timers stories." Anyway, in 1990 Bob
Coleman arranged a sword appreciation tour. His wife,
Bill MIller, Paul Davidson, Mel Oka, Ray Deadman, Bob
Lewertt, Keith Hostler and myself went. Seems like
someone else but oh that memory button......Anyway too
much happened to repot it all but we did visit ( and
also dine with) Michihiro Tanabe. He laid out maybe 50
swords for us and we kanteied some. Kotetsu's , Kiya
Maro , freaking all the heavy hitters. The deadest
feeling block of metal was the Kiyo maru. Nothing to
it. We aslo went out for a really cool dinner served
by Geisha style chicks. Mr. Sugiyama (who was a
polishing agent for Tanabe) attended as well as Gordon
Robson. I have a back piece of a Samurai with a
naginata and made a fool of myself running around
wothout a shirt on. Jeez, no class. Years later when I
met with Tanabe at the NBTHK convention in Osaka (Paul
Davidson and I) Tanabe says "Oh you're the tattoo
guy!" Well I guess it's beter t be
remembered.....than........Bob Elder

If ignorance is bliss, how come I'm not ecstatic!?

messages.subject: finally got my tsuba and some new pics
messages.msgSnippet: The Weight Bamboo guard. Has obvious forging layers in the mimi ( quite flat ) 81 x 79 x 6mm, The holes do not go all the way through. This looks older than
messages.messageBody:
The Weight Bamboo guard.

Has obvious forging layers in the mimi ( quite flat ) 81 x 79 x 6mm, The
holes do not go all the way through. This looks older than all the late
Edo tsuba I have.

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/personal/tsuba/weights-babmboo.jpg

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/personal/tsuba/mimi.jpg

This is the other, small wakizashi guard, quite fine. 65 x 62 x 3mm.
Looks like long running bones but very very subtle. This looks mid/late
Edo I feel.

http://www.nihontomessageboard.com/personal/tsuba/wakizashi-tsuba.jpg

cheers

Rich

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Yagyu family pattern book
messages.msgSnippet: Jim, That one is on my want list.  I recently did acquire: Yagyu Tsuba by Miki Yoshikazu 1997. David ... From: Jim Gilbert To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
messages.messageBody:
Jim,

That one is on my want list. I recently did acquire: Yagyu Tsuba by Miki Yoshikazu 1997.

David
----- Original Message -----
From: Jim Gilbert
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Sunday, July 31, 2005 8:18 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Yagyu family pattern book


David,
There is a version of the first 36 designs reproduced in "Owari to Mikawa no Tsubako," Okamoto Yasutomo, Toyohashi 1983. It's a must have book for people interested in Owari region guards.

Jim


The current Sotheby's tsuba auction references the Yagyu family pattern book on various Yagyu lots.

Examples:

Lot 828:

"The design is illustrated in the Yagyu family pattern book, no. 78"

Lot 829
"The design is no. 39 in the Yagyu family pattern book"



I've heard of its existence but never heard of it being published. Has anyone else?



David Zincavage


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Yagyu family pattern book
messages.msgSnippet: The Haynes/Torigoye copy is in a different hand.  I haven t seen a full version of anyone s copy in print.  I wonder how many different hand copies there are.
messages.messageBody:
The Haynes/Torigoye copy is in a different hand. I haven't seen a full version of anyone's copy in print. I wonder how many different hand copies there are.

Jim



David,

Thank you! That was exactly what I recalled but could not place.

Craig

messages.subject: Re: Yagyu family pattern book
messages.msgSnippet: Mr. Haynes says in one of the catalogues, the one with the Yagyu write-up that went into the Aesthetic Study, that he had a copy given to him by Torigoye,
messages.messageBody:
Mr. Haynes says in one of the catalogues, the one with the Yagyu write-up
that went into the Aesthetic Study, that he had a copy given to him by
Torigoye, which he planned to publish one day.

David Z.

messages.subject: Re: Yagyu family pattern book
messages.msgSnippet: David, There are a few Yagyu guards illustrated from the pattern book on p.189-190 of Haynes Catalog #9. It seems like I saw more of the pattern book published
messages.messageBody:
David,

There are a few Yagyu guards illustrated from the pattern book on
p.189-190 of Haynes Catalog #9. It seems like I saw more of the
pattern book published somewhere, but at the moment I can't find what
that would be.

Perhaps someone with a better memory or filing system will help out.

Craig

--
Craig Harris
Books from and about Asia
www.bridgeofdreams.com
